message.content:
We need to “build up” the final main business revenue – in an income statement that usually reflects sales revenue – by going through every transaction and including only those whose “type” is “Sale” (ignoring other items like purchases, expenses, interest, etc.). Then we sum the “after_tax_amount” values from each sale record.

Below is our walkthrough step‐by‐step.

Step 1. Read the transactions and “filter out” only the sales. In the table the rows whose type is “Sale” are (using the id’s to mark them):

• Sale20240102001 after_tax_amount = 177912.70

Step 2. Sum all these after_tax_amount values. (Our “running tally” – see the calculation below – is done in order.)

Step 3. The “Main Business Revenue” used in the income statement is the sum of the sale revenue (after tax) – which is 2,874,165.95.

Thus the final result is:

{
  "solution": {"Main Business Revenue": "2874165.95"}
}
